items.caption: Art samples
items.body: <!-- Image credit: https://www.flickr.com/photos/markchadwick/6515466657 -->

items.caption: AvsP video editor
items.body:
http://www.avisynth.nl/users/qwerpoi/

An open source graphical interface to the video editing programming language AviSynth. The program was written using wxPython with C++ bindings to the AviSynth language.This was a personal side project that I started in 2006 that eventually became adopted by thousands of people and translated by the community in nearly a dozen languages. I also created the website with tutorials and documentation as well as supported users in the doom9 forums.

Watch the video demonstration

items.caption: DSNotes Homebrew
items.body:
http://gamebrew.org/wiki/DSNotes

DSNotes is a homebrew application I wrote for the Nintendo DS. It was programmed in C using the PAlib library. It was designed to provide the fastest possible way to create and save a simple black and white bitmap drawing (only 6kb in size) - everything in the interface is a single click away.

Watch the video demonstration

items.caption: QuickFits Rails application
items.body:
https://github.com/alangster/my-quick-fits

QuickFits is a Ruby on Rails web application I worked on for my final group project at Dev Bootcamp. The app helps men choose an outfit each day based on a custom algorithm that takes into account matching colors, styles, current weather, and previously worn items. We incorporated camera access and JavaScript color analysis so users can catolog their wardrobe simply by taking pictures of their clothes.

items.caption: Asteria JavaScript game
items.body:
https://github.com/christianstanfield/robot-dino-girl

Asteria is a game I worked on for one of my group projects at Dev Bootcamp. It was written using the Phaser JavaScript game framework.

items.caption: Frontend Framework comparison
items.body:
https://github.com/acltc/javascript-frameworks

This is a repo I created to compare different frontend frameworks to use with a Ruby on Rails backend. Kind of like the site TodoMVC, but in this case the comparison is equivalent commit by commit. Each framework is represented in a different branch, and each commit is identical across frameworks. This means that the commit "Toggle the bio on click" exists in every branch, which makes it easy to compare how much effort it takes to implement each feature in the different frameworks. So far frameworks include Angular 1, Angular 2, React (using the react-rails gem), and Vue.

items.caption: HTML5 Canvas with Redux
items.body:
http://peterxjang.com

I built this website itself using my own implementation of a drawing library in a functional style using HTML5 Canvas and Redux (no React!). As a result the entire JavaScript codebase weighs in around 10Kb gzipped, which is far less than most Canvas libraries that I've come across. This means that by inlining the css and js, the HTML weighs less than 14Kb, meaning it loads in milliseconds, even on mobile devices.

Features include panning and scaling both the canvas as well as editing individual items, which support for touch input devices as well as mouse input. The code was written using ES6 via Babel and webpack for module bundling, with the only 3rd party production dependency being Redux.

Watch the video demonstration

items.caption: Atlanta
items.body: I lived in Atlanta for several months in 2007 working as a consultant for Roh Square. Didn't get a good sense of the city, since my job kept me pretty busy.

items.caption: Cancun
items.body: Only stayed here for a night on the way to Cuba. Got the sense that it was the Las Vegas of Mexico, didn't see much more than that. Food was pretty good, though.

items.caption: Chicago
items.body: I was born and raised in Chicago (either in the city or the suburbs). I've lived in Rogers Park and Pilsen, as well as the suburbs of Glenview and Niles.

items.caption: Anaheim
items.body: Only been here for a ASME mechanical engineering conference to present some of my research. Stopped by Disneyland but didn't go inside.

items.caption: Orlando
items.body: Only visited once as part of a high school orchestra trip. We spent a few days at Disneyworld and even got to perform by the waterfront.

items.caption: Havana
items.body: Stayed here for a few days in support of the Cuban people. Beautiful city, lots of history and a very different perspective compared to day to day US life.

items.caption: London
items.body: Stayed here for a few days in the financial district. Beautiful city, although I wasn't too keen on the food. Pretty expensive due to the difference between the US dollar and the pound, although my trip was pre-Brexit.

items.caption: New Orleans
items.body: Stayed here twice, once for an AFT teacher union multi-city meeting and another time for a weekend vacation. Absolutely beautiful architecture and culture, great food. Wasn't fond of Bourbon Street, but there's plenty to do here without being too touristy. Highly recommended.

items.caption: Niagra Falls
items.body: Drove here from Chicago for a family vacation. I don't remember too much other than the long drive (I get carsick sometimes).

items.caption: Paris
items.body: Stayed here for a few days at a nice AirBnB. I know a little French from high school, so it was fun to at least attempt to comminicate with local Parisians. Really enjoyed my stay here, there are a lot of diverse neighborhoods and a very cool vibe.

items.caption: Seoul
items.body: Came to visit my family, it was my first visit to Korea as an adult. One of the most densely packed cities I've traveled to, there was a great energy and hustle and bustle no matter where you went, no matter what the time. As a person who uses public transportation regularly, I was very impressed with the public transportation system throughout Korea - efficient and shockingly clean!

items.caption: Washington DC
items.body: Been here with my family as well as for a high school orchestra trip. Our orchestra actually got to perform in the White House, which is a pretty big honor for any kind of performer. So I've got that going for me, which is nice.

items.caption: Venice
items.body: Stayed here for a few days (we actually booked an AirBnB on Lido, which is an island right off of Venice). It can be very touristy, but there are a lot of beautiful places if you're willing to venture off the beaten path.

items.caption: Muskogee
items.body: I lived here for a few months as part of my consulting work for Roh Square. I actually lived in the Hampton hotel pictured here. My job was pretty stressful so I didn't really get to enjoy Oklahoma, but I can say that the people there are some of the nicest people you will ever meet in general.

items.caption: Las Vegaas
items.body: Came here for a teacher conference on standards based grading, which sounds pretty boring but was actually a really fun time (partly because I was with some great coworkers). Las Vegas can be a really sketchy experience, but there's actually a lot of really cool stuff to do and see, even if you don't drink or gamble (which I don't).

items.caption: Rudy Lozano Leadership Academy
items.body: I worked here for 6 years as a high school math teacher. The absolute toughest job I have ever worked, hands down. But a very rewarding experience, I learned a great deal about people here. I'd like to think that I learned as much from the students as they did through me. I aspire to keep the social justice aspect of the school alive in all the work that I continue to do.

items.caption: University of Illinois
items.body: I did my undergraduate in Mechanical Engineering here, followed by my masters in Mechanical Engineering, and later my masters in Education. During my masters in Mechanical Engineering, I started getting into heavy duty programming. My first research project was to take an existing non-linear optimization algorithm writtin in C which took 3 hours to run and make it run in 10 minutes using bitwise compression techniques. During this time I programmed multiple appliactions in C, C++, Matlab, and Python.

items.caption: Roh Square Consulting
items.body: My first job after finishing my masters in Mechanical Engineering was for Roh Square consulting, which was essentially a one person consulting operation. I was hired to work at location in both Muskogee, OK and Atlanta, GA. Our client was Georgia Pacific, a Fortune 500 company with a focus on manufacturing paper products. I worked on optimization of their paper manufacturing process at their Oklahoma factory, which involved creating mathematical linear and non-linear optimization algorighms and implementing them in both Excel VBA and VBA.net.

items.caption: Dev Bootcamp
items.body: After teaching for 6 years, I wanted to have an opportunity to flex my programming muscles once again. I enrolled in the Chicago location of Dev Bootcamp to kick start my career as a web developer. It was a great but rigorous experience. By this point I had been programming for over 10 years, so of course it wasn't quite the same experience compared to someone who just started to learn to program. My hat goes off to every student who is capable of making it through the program.

items.caption: BLUE1647
items.body: After graduating from Dev Bootcamp, I taught several Ruby on Rails courses here at BLUE1647. This was a great opportunity for me to combine both of my passions - programming and teaching, and all for a cause that benefits the community to boot. Plus I lived really close by to the original Pilsen location. A great experience, I'm still a member of the organization.

items.caption: Everspring
items.body: My first web development job was at Everspring, a startup focused on working with universities to create online curriculum taught by existing faculty. Our team was responsible for implementing a new backend system using the Scala Play framework with a MongoDB database as well as a new frontend codebase using the Ember framework. No one on our team had experience with either framework (which was chosen before we arrived), so we had to learn both Scala and Ember from scratch - definitely an interesting experience. I also created a small project using React to determine the viability of the framework in our production.

items.caption: Actualize
items.body: I currently work at Actualize, a coding bootcamp plus apprenticeship, as the Dean of Instruction as well as a Chicago lead instructor. The program has a very strong focus on education (many of the staff have advanced degrees in education), which makes it a perfect fit for my skillset. The program itself is part time, which means students do not need to quit their full time jobs to participate. We focus all our energies across multiple cities into a single curriculum, which we continue to refine using communities of practice.

items.caption: The Art of Game Design
items.body:
by Jesse Schell

A fantastic book on every aspect of game design (not just video game design). Game design is really about how to make something fun, which means many of the ideas here translate perfectly into other fields such as curriculum and instruction.

items.caption: CSS Secrets
items.body:
by Lea Verou

A unique book that manages to take a bunch of seemingly random tips and combine it into a story that really helps you understand CSS better. Covers some of the most advanced CSS techniques I've ever seen, yet it's easy for a beginner to pick up and understand. The typing effect on this website was based on one of the many tips covered in the book. Can't recommend it highly enough.

items.caption: The Non-Designer's Design Book
items.body:
by Robin Williams

The best instructional book I've ever read. If you've ever made a word document, you're a designer, which means you must read this book. Eye opening in terms of understanding how to see design in everything you see, broken down into 4 simple categories.

items.caption: Presentation Zen
items.body:
by Garr Reynolds

A great book on how to make presentations that don't suck. Really, it's astounding to see how many awful presentations exist in the world, this book gives clear and simple guidelines on how to make effective presentations that are both beautiful and informative.

items.caption: The Humane Interface
items.body:
by Jef Raskin

The most influential tech book I have ever read (that sadly few people have even heard of). This site itself is inspired by some of the ideas Jef describes here. He was so far ahead of his time, we haven't even scratched the surface of what he proposed. Today's technology would be in a far better place if more people knew of his work.

items.caption: A Whole New Mind
items.body:
by Dan Pink

A unique argument for design as the distinguishing skill for the new age. Written with a fresh voice, a lot of interesting takeaways from this book. Recommended.

items.caption: Drive
items.body:
by Dan Pink

A well written book on what motivates people. Dan Pink has a knack for breaking concepts down in a compelling way, many ideas here that are deeply relevant for teachers.

items.caption: Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain
items.body:
by Betty Edwards

The right-brain/left-brain science here may be oversimplified, but the content in this book will blow you away. Betty Edwards claim is that anyone can learn to draw, it's simply a matter of building a muscle that many of us stopped using as children (and she explains why). The results of her students from a week long workshop are nothing short of astounding.

items.caption: Made to Stick
items.body:
by Chip & Dan Heath

A well written book on what makes an idea memorable, a.k.a. sticky. A bit over-explained at times, but well written and many actionable takeaways here.

items.caption: Making Comics
items.body:
by Scott McCloud

This is a book on making comics, but it really is something more. Scott McCloud's ability to explain concepts in comic form is peerless, there's nothing remotely like this. Even if you don't have any interest in making comics, you will learn an amazing amount about telling stories and designing communication in a short and simple book. A work of art.

items.caption: Wolverine sketch
items.body: Sketched on a Windows tablet. One of my first experiments using color on a tablet, turned out pretty well for a basic experiment.

items.caption: Naruto
items.body: Sketched on a Windows tablet. Quick drawing made for my nephew. Kind of messed up the eyes, but not bad for a quick sketch. Naruto is not a great show, btw.

items.caption: Hand sketch
items.body: Sketched on a Windows tablet. A practice exercise on drawing what you see.

items.caption: Swordsman sketch
items.body: Sketched on a Windows tablet. Loosely based on the manga Rurouni Kenshin (which is a great manga and anime).

items.caption: Caminos Logo
items.body: Official logo designed for Caminos de Michoacan, a local bar in the Pilsen Chicago neighborhood. Caminos means 'road' in Spanish, hence the letter A here, a subtle touch that I'm not sure how many people notice.

items.caption: Graffiti
items.body: Drawn on paper using markers. I started learning grafitti as a high school teacher. Each teacher at my school ran an activity club based on student interest, so I ran the grafitti club. Although I had never done grafitti before, I had many students who actively practiced and were willing to teach me and other students, so it worked out well.

items.caption: GitHub
items.body: My GitHub portfolio

items.caption: LinkedIn
items.body: My LinkedIn profile

items.caption: Medium
items.body: My Medium blog

items.caption: Melbourne
items.body: An awesome city, lots of different neighborhoods to check out, each one very different than the next. I only spent a few days here, would love to go back and check out everything it has to offer.

items.caption: Sydney
items.body: I enjoyed this city far more than I was expecting to - it's definitely can be a commercial and touristy kind of place, but there's so much energy and good vibes all around. The city is so densely packed, you can walk around and see a tremendous amount in a single day - that's my kind of vacation!

items.caption: Modern JavaScript Explained For Dinosaurs
items.body:
Read the full article

An overview of modern JavaScript, explained for beginners as well as seasoned developers who haven't been following the recent trends. One of Medium's top stories on ​10/21/17.

items.caption: Modern CSS Explained For Dinosaurs
items.body:
Read the full article

An overview of modern CSS, explained for beginners as well as seasoned developers who haven't been following the recent trends. The #1 post on Hacker News on ​2/5/18.

items.caption: A minimalist guide to tmux
items.body:
Read the full article

A simple guide for getting started with tmux, which is a useful tool to get more functionality out of a terminal. The #16 post on Hacker News on ​11/26/17.

items.caption: Comparing Frontend Approaches
items.body:
Read the full article

A comparison of jQuery, Vue.js, Vue.js with components, React, and Elm. These different approaches are compared by building the exact same app (a clone of the default Mac Notes app) each time. Similar to TodoMVC, except each app is built with explanations for each feature as they're built, which makes the pros and cons of each approach clear and understandable.

items.caption: How To Learn Vim: A Four Week Plan
items.body:
Read the full article

A guide on how to learn Vim incrementally. Even if it's not your primary editor, knowing how to use a text editor from the terminal is a nice superpower to have.

items.caption: A Metric-Based Approach to Two-Dimensional (2D) Tool-Path Optimization for High-Speed Machining
items.body:
Read the full article

Conventional tool-path generation strategies are readily available to generate geometrically feasible trajectories. Such approaches seldom take into consideration physical process concerns or dynamic system limitations. In the present work, an approach for improving a geometrically feasible tool-path trajectory based on quantifiable process metrics is developed. Two specific measures of toolpath quality are incorporated into the iterative improvement algorithm: instantaneous path curvature and instantaneous cutter engagement. These metrics are motivated by a desire to minimize acceleration requirements and maintain a stable steady-state cutting process during high-speed machining. The algorithm has been implemented for two-dimensional contiguous end-milling operations with flat end-mills, and case studies are presented to illustrate the approach.

items.caption: What is Teachable Code?
items.body:
See publication

An article about what makes code teachable and how that's often not the same as what makes code readable. The article originally appeared here.

items.caption: A Functional Canvas Approach With Redux
items.body:
Read the full article

An overview of how to use the HTML5 Canvas API in a functional style (as opposed to the object oriented style used by many libraries). A good primer on Redux as well as functional approaches in general. The approach described here is how I built this site itself.
